original_title: Sri Lanka exports down 5.59-pct in May, apparels, coconut slip
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s merchandise exports fell 5.59 percent in May 2023 from a year earlier to 989.7 million US dollars, due to a drop in apparel, textile and coconut exports, data from the island’s Export Development Board showed.
In the first five months to May, merchandise exports fell 8.29 percent 4,835.99 million US dollars from a year earlier.
Export earnings from Apparel & Textiles fell by 14.55 percent from a year earlier to 412.43 Million US dollars in May 2023.
Demand from Western nations are falling as pandemic era money printing is phased out. Commodity prices are also falling amid tighter policy.
Coconut based products fell 5.57 percent during the period from a year earlier to 66.6 million US dollars.
Tea, which accounted for 12 percent of merchandise exports, increased by 24.16 percent to 116.33 million US dollars.
Export of Rubber and Rubber Finished products have increased by 0.20 percent to 76.84 million US dollars, with rubber tyres and tubes up 6.82 percent.
Earnings from Activated Carbon fell 4.23 percent to 14.05 million dollars.
Spices and essential Oils increased by 26.24 percent to 27.13 million dollars.
Out of top 10 export markets, Italy and France markets have shown a positive performance during the month of May 2023 from a year ago.
UAE market has shown a positive performance during the month of May 2023 compared to the corresponding period of previous year.

Exports to United States of America, Sri Lanka’s single largest export destination, fell 15.25 percent to 225.8 million US dollars and United States of America fell by 16.38 percent to 1140.70 million US dollars in the period of January to May 2023 compared to the same period in 2022. (Colombo/ June 28/2023)
